description.plain:
Salt-N-Pepa is arguably the most successful female rap group of all time. The group began with Cheryl “Salt” James and Sandra “Pepa” Denton meeting while studying to be nurses. James got Denton a job at a Sears department store, where her boyfriend Hurby “Luv Bug” Azor also worked. Azor was studying music production and he asked them to help on a school project, an answer record to Doug E. Fresh’s “The Show” they named “The Showstopper” – recorded in 1985 under the name Supernature.

After the legendary Queens DJ Marley Marl played “The Showstopper” on his radio show, the group began getting booked for shows. One lyric in “The Showstopper” was ‘We the salt and pepper’, and people kept requesting ‘that salt and pepper song’, so they changed their name to Salt-N-Pepa. Deejay Deidra “Spinderella” Ropa was added soon after.

SNP’s debut album Hot, Cool, & Vicious originally spawned a minor hit in the UK with “My Mike Sounds Nice” in early 1987. But it was the re-release of a remix of “Push It”, originally a quickly-thrown together b-side for their fall ‘87 single “Tramp”, that shot the group into international stardom. The song reached the top 10 in eleven countries around the world in 1988.

The group had continued international success throughout first half of the 1990s with hits like “Expression”, “Do You Really Want Me”, “You Showed Me”, “Shoop” and “Whatta Man” featuring En Vogue. Their 1991 hit “Let’s Talk About Sex” was used to raise awareness about the AIDS epidemic in the United States at the time. SNP won a Grammy for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group in 1994 for “None of Your Business”.

The group released their last album Brand New in 1997, featuring a modest hit “R U Ready,” before disbanding. SNP continues to tour and make television appearances, including the VH-1 reality series The Salt-N-Pepa Show and Let’s Talk About Pep.

songs.full_title: Push It by Salt-N-Pepa
songs.title: Push It

description.plain:
“Push It” is Salt-N-Pepa’s first hit song and one of their most famous. Although often mistaken as a song about sex, the group insists “Push It” is about dancing.

Written by friend/record production student Hurby Luv Bug, the song was originally not included on SNP’s debut album Hot, Cool and Vicious, but instead added at the last minute as the B-side of that album’s single “Tramp” in 1987 after being recorded in their producer’s bathroom.

The ‘Mixx-it’ remix of “Push It” by DJ Cameron Paul featured on the flipside of the “Tramp” 7" single became an unexpected nationwide hit, sending its A-side up the R&B Chart to #21 in the fall of ‘87.

“Push It (Remix)” soon got its own release and reached #19 on the Hot 100 in early 1988. That success spread overseas with the song reaching the top 10 in ten countries.

“Tramp”/“Push It” initially climbed to #41 in the UK in early ‘88. However, it re-entered the chart after the group performed it at Nelson Mandela’s 70th Birthday Tribute concert held at Wembley that June, rocketing the single up to the #2 spot in July.

During this success of Cameron Paul’s remix of “Push It”, Hot, Cool & Vicious was re-released with Paul’s mix as its first track.

Soon, when “Push It” was certified Gold, then Platinum by the RIAA, it made Salt N Pepa the first female rap group to do both. The track was also nominated for the Grammys first-ever Best Rap Performance award in 1989, losing to DJ Jazzy Jeff & Fresh Prince’s “Parents Just Don’t Understand”.

“Push It” continues to receive accolades decades after its release. In 2008, VH1 ranked “Push It” at #9 on their 100 Greatest Songs of Hip Hop. In 2011, “Push It” was ranked #446 on Rolling Stone’s list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

description.plain:
From Salt n Pepa’s 1993 album, Very Necessary. It peaked at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, #1 on the Billboard Rap charts and was nominated for a Grammy for Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group. It was also ranked #23 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of the 90s.

This song samples Linda Lyndell’s 1968 song “What a Man.”

From Salt n Pepa’s 1993 album, Very Necessary. It peaked at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, #1 on the Billboard Rap charts and was nominated for a Grammy for Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group. It was also ranked #23 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of the 90s.

This song samples Linda Lyndell’s 1968 song “What a Man.”

songs.full_title: Let's Talk About Sex by Salt-N-Pepa
songs.title: Let’s Talk About Sex

description.plain:
“Let’s Talk About Sex” was the fourth single from SNP’s 1990 album Black’s Magic. It was also the album’s highest-charting song in the US, reaching #13 in November 1991 – surpassing their previous highest-charter “Push It” (which had hit #19 three years earlier).

The song was known for its frank discussion about the positive aspects of sex and things to consider before indulging. In Tricia Rose’s Hip Hop Wars she explains that a song like “Let’s Talk About Sex” proves that “explicit is not always exploitative”.

In 1992, ABC newscaster Peter Jennings hosted the special Living in the Age of AIDS and asked SNP to revise the lyrics of the song for it, so they created a modified version of the track named “Let’s Talk About AIDS,” and focused on the topic of practicing safe sex. This new version was released as its own single, then included on certain releases of SNP’s next album Very Necessary and as a b-side on two of its singles.

songs.full_title: Ain't Nuthin' But a She Thing by Salt-N-Pepa
songs.title: Ain’t Nuthin’ But a She Thing
songs.title_with_featured: Ain't Nuthin' But a She Thing

description.plain:
“Ain’t Nuthin' But a She Thing” is a Top 40 single by Salt-N-Pepa from a women’s empowerment themed compilation album of the same name. The title itself subverts Dr. Dre’s “Nuthin' But a G Thang.” for the song’s feminist theme.

Like “Independent,” a previous female empowerment anthems from Salt-N-Pepa, “Ain’t Nuthin'” was both written and produced by Cheryl “Salt” James.

The sex-positive and largely black-and-white music video shows the women of Salt-N-Pepa taking on roles traditionally filled by men (i.e. law enforcement officer, auto mechanic, firefighter, astronaut). The video closes dramatically with Pepa playing a woman in a cocktail dress successfully fighting off sexual assault in a darkened alley.

body.plain:
“Ain’t Nuthin' But a She Thing” is a Top 40 single by Salt-N-Pepa from a women’s empowerment themed compilation album of the same name. The title itself subverts Dr. Dre’s “Nuthin' But a G Thang.” for the song’s feminist theme.

Like “Independent,” a previous female empowerment anthems from Salt-N-Pepa, “Ain’t Nuthin'” was both written and produced by Cheryl “Salt” James.

The sex-positive and largely black-and-white music video shows the women of Salt-N-Pepa taking on roles traditionally filled by men (i.e. law enforcement officer, auto mechanic, firefighter, astronaut). The video closes dramatically with Pepa playing a woman in a cocktail dress successfully fighting off sexual assault in a darkened alley.

songs.full_title: Do You Want Me (Remix) by Salt-N-Pepa
songs.title: Do You Want Me (Remix)

description.plain:
“Do You Want Me”, the third single from SNP’s third album, became their third top 40 hit in the US and third top 5 in the UK in the spring of 1991.

There are two popular versions of the song that were both originally released as “Remix”:


‘Video Version’ by Hurby Luv Bug, released in the US simply as “Remix”, but called “Original” overseas.
‘European Version’ by Ben Liebrand, simply labeled as “Remix” in Europe, but called “European Remix” in the US.



This release features both.

songs.full_title: Shake Your Thang by Salt-N-Pepa (Ft. E.U.)
songs.title: Shake Your Thang

description.plain:
A funky 80’s song emphasizing the need for women to avoid complete emotional and financial dependence on men. Other songs like “Tramp” express these feminist themes of female autonomy.

On the cover of the song, it shows the ladies dressed in custom-made Dapper Dan leather jackets that used fashion to represent their femininity and power.

songs.full_title: Expression by Salt-N-Pepa (Ft. Jacci McGhee)
songs.title: Expression

description.plain: “Expression” is the lead single released from Salt-n-Pepa’s third album, Blacks' Magic. The song was both written and produced by member Cheryl “Salt” James. The song became the group’s second single to reach the top 40 in the US, peaking at number 28 on the Billboard Hot 100 while also topping the Hot Rap Singles chart at number one, becoming their first song to do so. The single was certified gold by the RIAA on February 28, 1990 before reaching platinum status less than three months later on May 25.

songs.full_title: Let's Talk About AIDS by Salt-N-Pepa
songs.title: Let’s Talk About AIDS

description.plain:
In late 1991, SNP’s song “Let’s Talk About Sex” was a top 20 hit in the US. In 1992, ABC newscaster Peter Jennings hosted the special Living in the Age of AIDS and asked SNP to revise the lyrics of the song for it, so they created a modified version of the track named “Let’s Talk About AIDS,” and focused on the topic of practicing safe sex.

This new version was also released as a single with proceeds benefiting the TJ Martell Foundation, the music industry’s largest non-profit foundation for cancer, leukemia and AIDS research.

Later, the song was also included on certain releases of SNP’s next album Very Necessary and as a b-side on two of its singles.

songs.full_title: Heaven or Hell by Salt-N-Pepa (Ft. Styowlz)
songs.title: Heaven or Hell

description.plain:
Heaven Or Hell, Also Known as Heaven ‘n Hell (for the video and single), is the Third single from Salt-n-Pepa’s fourth album, Very Necessary.

The Second verse was performed by a duo called Styowlz.

A portion of Styowlz’s verse and a portion of Salt’s 3rd were re-recorded with different lyrics for the radio and video edit.

The song’s title is derived from “Heaven and Hell Is on Earth” by 20th Century Steel Band, which the chorus interpolates.

songs.embed_content: Read “Heaven or Hell” by Salt-N-Pepa on Genius
songs.recording_location: Sound Trek Studios, Bayside Sound & Power Play Studios (Long Island, NY)

The way half a million disappeared

(Huh?) Me (what?), me, yeah, little old me

I'm all that I got, Pops, and that's a lot, Hops
I'd rather rot in jail before I ho-hop
Go 'head, me, tell 'em
They may be hard of hearing
So keep yellin' at the top of your lungs
Now everybody's got guns
They wanna be hard rocks and not be a fool
That buys a history book

Well everybody be damned, her father's in jail
Sister's on the corner screamin', "Booty for sale"
Mom spends the night gettin' drunk with her uncle
Her brother's sellin' radios and toasters by the trunkful
See, every man she ever messed would wind up dead
Some might fall in jail, others runnin' from the Feds
(The only thing she ever loved was a piece of lead)
And that's a double-barrelled pump underneath the bed

Some people wanna fill the world with silly love songs and looney tunes

There's good news and bad news, military coups
